articles.title: Online Coding Round Experience | Atlassian | Summer 2025 Internship
articles.summary: I recently participated in the online coding round for Atlassian's Summer 2025 internship opportunity for the Software Development Engineering role. The round consisted of three questions that had to be solved within 90 minutes. Here's a detailed acc
articles.content:
I recently participated in the online coding round for Atlassian's Summer 2025 internship opportunity for the Software Development Engineering role. The round consisted of three questions that had to be solved within 90 minutes. Here's a detailed account of my experience:

**Question 1: Merging Two Linked Lists**
The first question involved two linked lists, head1 and head2, and two integers, a and b. We had to merge the second linked list into the first one such that the ath node of the first linked list points to the head of the second linked list, and the tail of the second linked list points to the bth node of the first linked list. Essentially, we needed to insert the second linked list between the ath and bth nodes of the first linked list.

I managed to solve this problem within 15 minutes, passing all 15 test cases successfully.

**Question 2: Minimizing Cost with Coupons**
The second question provided a list of positive integers called price, where price[i] represents the price of the ith item. We were also given an integer m, which represents the number of discount coupons available. Each coupon could be applied to any item, and if x coupons were applied to an item priced at p, its new price would be floor(p / (2^x)). The goal was to minimize the total cost of buying all items using the coupons.

I approached this problem with a greedy algorithm. My strategy was to apply coupons to the maximum element in the price list until all coupons were used up or the maximum element became zero. After that, I summed up all the elements in the list to get the minimum cost. I passed 12 out of 15 test cases; the remaining test cases resulted in a Time Limit Exceeded (TLE) error.

**Question 3: Counting Non-Overlapping Intervals**
The third question involved two lists of positive integers of equal lengths, starting and ending, where starting[i] and ending[i] represent an interval (both inclusive). The task was to find the number of unique triplets of non-overlapping intervals.

I initially thought of solving this problem using dynamic programming and began coding a recursive approach. However, due to time constraints, I could only pass 7 out of 15 test cases, with the remaining test cases resulting in TLE or Memory Limit Exceeded (MLE) errors.

Overall, it was a challenging yet enriching experience. I learned a lot about optimizing my approach and managing time effectively under pressure.

**Tip:** The order of questions in the actual assessment was different from what is listed here. I recommend quickly reading through all the problems first and then solving them in increasing order of difficulty. Tackling easier questions first helps build confidence, reduces stress, and provides a sense of accomplishment during the assessment.

Thanks for reading!

articles.title: 6 months+ Interview Prep Journey [Laid Off]
articles.summary:
Education: B.Tech NIT
Years of Experience: 6
Prior Experience: MNC. Impacted by Layoff (> 6 months)

Was Impacted by Layoffs in First week of March. Took >
articles.content:
Education: B.Tech NIT
Years of Experience: 6
Prior Experience: MNC. Impacted by Layoff (> 6 months)

Was Impacted by Layoffs in First week of March. Took > 6 Months to land offers. Sharing Month wise preparation and interview experiences.

**March-April** **(*The initial burst of Motivation*)**

The news came as a shock to me and took couple of days to even register what actually happened. Started doing LC on a daily basis with occasional Design questions(HLD).
Started applying from 2nd/3rd week of march, got a couple of calls but couldnt make it past the initial stages.
Was still very confident to close out the job hunt in 6-8 weeks.

**Phonepe**: https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/5058789/phonepe-sde2-bangalore-55yoe [Reject]
Interviewed for **Arista Networks** but there were a lot of questions around Netwokring, hence couldnt clear it.[Reject]
Appeared for OA of **New Relic**, cleared the test and was asked to travel to a different city for in person interviews. Sadly i was going home at that time for Holi and asked the recruiter if its possible to reschedule it to next week to which she agreed. But tried reaching out to her multiple times the following week and didnt get any response.

Wasnt getting as many calls from recruiters as i expected earlier. Since i had very recently switched to the last company, my profile was not even getting shortlisted due to frequent job changes.

Started to lose confidence because of lack of responses.

**May (*The Ghosting Phase*)**

Thats when i started to feel a bit(more) anxious. Till now only a couple of people around me knew about my job status as was too embarrassed to share it with my friends/family.

Started to get some responses from companies. Recruiter screens were getting scheduled but when i joined, no one attended the meeting. Inspite of Multiple followups on mails and on calls, didnt get a single response back from them.
**OCI** scheduled a recruiter pre screen and never showed up.

**Microsoft** Recruiter reached out for a hiring drive, got my availability, didnt get any invite. Tried reaching out to the recruiter and via some friends internally as well, was updated that the interview will be scheduled the following week, nothing happened again.
This happened 2-3 times and eventually i never got any invite for the interview.

Was paralelly appearing for whatever Online Assessments i was getting from Microsoft or any other companies but even after clearing the tests, i wasnt getting any responses.

By the Second week of May, started to maintain streaks on daily questions on Leetcode and was more motivated than ever.

Dont remember if i gave any substantial interviews during this period.

**June (*The month of Realization*)**

Kept on maintaining the streaks till June Mid.

Gave a few interviews:
**Microsoft**:  https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/5338820/microsoft-hiring-drive-june-7-bangalore [Reject]
Never got any update from the recruiter. All i ever got was "***We are still waiting for the feedback***" for months.

But still nothing seemed to be working out. Either i was somehow being put up with some unrealistic hard questions in interviews or i just messed up big time.

Again got Ghosted by couple of Companies.

1. **Coackroach Labs** recruiter sync was scheduled, was recheduled multiple times but the recruiter never showed up.
2. Was shortlisted for **Zepto** drive and some other companies, never received any invites.
3. Cleared Online assessment for **Salesforce**, got the call from recruiter for an in person interview in bangalore in next couple of days but sadly i was in my hometown at that time. Requested to have the interview a few days later as it wasnt possible to travel back, but got no response even after multiple followups.

I am no expert on the definition of depression but i didnt have anything to look forward to for the next day, started being in my own shell, didnt feel like sleeping at nights  since didnt want to face another day of applying for jobs and getting rejection mails. Stopped caring about myself, stopped talking to people, stopped enjoying anything and everything around me. Lost track of what day of the week it is. Thought about going to therapy multiple times but being jobless for months didnt go well with my finances so i guess it just felt like a waste of money.

Towards mid of June took some mental break, went on a solo trip, spent some time with family (pretending to work infront of them).

**July** (***Mixed***)

Had sever mental breakdowns towards end of June and first week of July.
First couple of weeks were spent in trying to analyze whats going wrong and where can i improve myself. Was seeing people around me getting jobs in 4-6 weeks after starting to apply for jobs which again made me lose my confidence even more and question myself.

*Still kept on lying to my friends' questions "How's work going?" with a smile on my face.*

Again appeared for Microsoft interviews in an attempt to clear it this time, sadly, it was worse than last time. Got rejected after first round itself.
**Microsoft** : https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/5465329/microsoft-sde2-bengaluru-drive-10-july [Reject]

By the 3rd week of July, started getting a few calls from recruiters and had a few initial syncups, exploratory, tech screen rounds.
Stepped up on the preparation even more.

**August-Sept** (Well, Finally!!!)

Gave up on everything (sleep, workout, hanging out with friends, movies, deactivated Instagram, limited my Phone screen time). Was feeling mentally and physically exhausted on a daily basis with just a few hours of sleep.
Fortunately, i had started to plan every day hour wise in order to accomodate interview schedules. Started giving 10+ interviews on a weekly basis and drives on the weekends (appeared for even more than 17 rounds of interviews a few weeks)

Things started to happen at OCI. Yes there were some places where i could have done better but was still looking forward to an offer as overall the interviews went good. But sadly received rejection. This took a heavy toll on me but just somehow pushed myself to not crib about it prepare for the other upcoming interviews.

**OCI** - https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/5758958/OCI-or-SMTS-or-6-Years-or-Reject [Reject]
**Microsoft** - Cleared initial OA and first 3 rounds, things messed up in the Hiring Manager round. [Reject]
Ghosted by **ServiceNow** and **PayPal**

Other Interview experiences during this period(Aug-Sept)-

**Wayfair**: https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/5756032/Wayfair-or-L3-or-Bangalore-or-Offer
**Adyen**: https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/5757749/Adyen-or-Java-Backend-or-Bangalore-or-Reject [Reject]
**Atlassian**: https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/5758945/Atlassian-or-P40-or-Offer-or-6-Years
**Spare**: https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/5757709/Spare-or-Backend-Developer-or-6-Years-or-Reject [Reject]
**Goldman Sachs**: https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/5756181/Goldman-Sachs-or-VP-or-Bangalore-or-Offer-or-6-Years
**Salesforce**: https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/5757562/Salesforce-or-SMTS-or-Offer-or-6-YOE
**AngelOne**: Rejected after round 2 [Reject]
**Stripe**: Cleared initial screening round. Rejected in virtual onsites [Reject]
**Zynga**: Rejected in first round [Reject]
**UIPath**: Rejected after second round [Reject]
**Allen**: Rejected after Round 2 [Reject]

Got the first offer from Wayfair but somehow just wanted to get something better considering the negative reviews around the company.
Eventually in the last week of August and first week of september got Offers from *Atlassian, Goldman Sachs and Salesforce* as well.

***Purpose of this Post?*** : Someone out there might be in the same boat as me and might be losing hope as i did multiple times. And a reminder to self as well to not lose hope.
***My suggestion?*** : Keep pushing! Eventually things will fall into place and your hard work will payoff. You will get what you deserve. Sometimes all you can do is keep working hard and do the hardest possible thing: **WAIT!** 
To the jobs I applied in march/April, i was getting responses in July. I hate to say this but sometmes, yes luck can definitely be a big factor when it comes to job hunt. 
Life is uncertain and more often than not things wont go even remotely close to how you planned them out. I had a lot of plans financially this year, everything just went down the drain. But this wont stop me from dreaming big and planning for my future.

***What kept me going through this period?*** : Guess i am someone who tries to find something positive out of every situation. Always thought *"I am gonna smile with a sense of pride when i make it past this phase and look back at it"*. Always thought about how this phase would make me a better person and how this would make me mentally stronger than ever.
Had weeks where i didnt have anything to look forward to, no interviews, no responses, so just kept pushing myself in the GYM. That sense of progress towards the end of every week in the gym did give me some relief.
Resorted to journaling, reading non-fictional books to keep myself sane through this period.
I am not an exceptional coder/developer. So tried working on my basics, even if i couldnt solve LC hard questions, kept on solving the medium/easy ones multiple times.
Leetcode community has been really helpful to me in my preparation, this collated list of interview experiences is just my attempt to give something back to the community.

***Resources followed for LLD/HLD:***

https://www.youtube.com/@TechDummiesNarendraL
https://www.udemy.com/course/system_design_lld_hld
https://www.youtube.com/@gkcs
https://www.youtube.com/@TheTechGranth/videos
https://www.youtube.com/@codeKarle
https://www.youtube.com/@SystemDesignInterview
Grokking the system design interview

***Leetcode Stats***: 300+ (~170 Medium)
Followed Blind 75 (54/75), Grind 169 (92/169), Neetcode 150 (80/150)
Used to follow company wise questions for preparations as well. 

Have missed a few interviews in between, will add if i am able to gather the required information.
Hope this helps whoever is reading it.

Keep moving forward! :)

articles.title: Atlassian | Senior Software Engineer | Bengaluru | August [Offer]
articles.summary:
Status: 10 YOE
Company: Walmart Global Tech
Location: Bengaluru
Date: August, 2024

1st round (Screening - Karat)
System Design questions:
1. Any concern
articles.content:
Status: 10 YOE
Company: Walmart Global Tech
Location: Bengaluru
Date: August, 2024

**1st round (Screening - Karat)**
System Design questions:
1. Any concerns with Consistent Hashing for multiple servers serving music uploading/streaming service
2. How would you handle large files that cannot fit in on a single machine
3. How would you scale your backend if your app is going from a single country to international app
4. Pros and cons of preloading hints or loading them from server for a game. Hints could be text/image/video based.

DSA:
1. Given a main word and a list of words, we need to find the word from the list whose anagram is present in a given string. HashMap problem
2. Find the coordinate of the given word in a n*m grid. Can start from any where and only move right/down

**2nd round (DSA)**
Given a stream of events with contentId and its popularity trend (+1/-1) we need to provide the most popular contentId at any given point in O(1)
Very similar to all oone data structure problem on Leetcode

**3rd round (Machine Coding)**
Rate limiter (Token bucket) Was asked to implement any one strategy

**4th round (High Level design)**
Tag management system: We need to design a tagging system that different systems like Confluence and Jira should be able to use to tag their assets.

**5th round (Management)**
1. Did you ever put your team ahead of your personal goals?
2. Did you take any initiative to improve the current system in your team?
3. Did you ever oppose someone’s technical approach and how?
4. What was the most challenging task you have faced?
5. Did you ever convince other teams to align with your thought process?

**6th round (Values)**
1. Biggest challenge you faced so far in your career?
2. Did you ever put your team ahead of your personal goals?
3. Did you face any issues with any teammates performance how did you?resolve it?
4. Did you ever commit anything and were not able to deliver it on time?
5. Did you drive any change in the team which ultimately for rejected?

Do not take 5th and 6th rounds lightly, they are as important as the technical rounds especially if it is P50 and above. Go prepared with good amount of examples

articles.title: Atlassian Software Engineer Intern Interview Experience
articles.summary:
There are two interviews for this opportunity.
1. First is technical round.
1. Second is HR round.

Technical Round
A user can make a maximum of 5 api call
articles.content:
There are two interviews for this opportunity.
1. First is technical round.
1. Second is HR round.

**Technical Round**
A user can make a maximum of 5 api calls in a minute, write a program to return true if the call is under 5 and false if exceeded. Once this was solved, the interviewer added more variations like add validations premium users and so on. To crack this round one must have good practice and knowledge of dsa.

**HR Round**
Atlassian has 5 values that are very important to them. They ask you situation based questions and they expect the answer to have the company's values. Here are some of the asked questions - explain the time you felt demotivated and how did you motivate yourself, how did you motivate your friend, explain how you got through a complex problem, how would you manage conflicts with a team member or manager etc. You need to prepare for this round thorughly and make sure you know the company's values enough to include them in your answers.

Best of luck to those preparing for it!

articles.title: [Read to know facts] - Atlassian revokes offer
articles.summary:
Hi All,
Must have heard one of the most talked about news in the LinkedIn.
Atlassian revokes FTE offers of new grads

[Disclaimer] - I am someone who has cl
articles.content:
Hi All,
Must have heard one of the most talked about news in the LinkedIn.
**Atlassian revokes FTE offers of new grads**

***[Disclaimer] - I am someone who has closely gone through this entire process at Atlassian, and hence fully worthy to write this post. However, I wouldn't claim myself to be a victim, because I know that nothing is permanent in this world (no job, no relation, not even our life!). This post is just for spilling some beans on this hi-fi incident, which has caught the attention of many influencer didis/bhaiyas. This post is not meant to hurt anybody's (company or human) sentiments.***


This unfortunate news comes just a couple of months before the anticipated joining date. Being so talented and facing this tough market situation, it's hard to accept the fact that one might be jobless after graduation.
This is the same remote company that claimed to be one of the most employee-centric workplaces on this planet. Also, the only company to have company values with slang words (do research if you do not know, but not hurting any company's sentiments, just an observation).

1. **Myth** - I have seen people comparing these folks with UPSC rankers, saying that cracking Atlassian is similar to cracking any Indian Government Job.
**Truth** - NO, IT'S NOT THAT TOUGH. PLEASE STOP SPREADING THESE FOOLISH RUMOURS. I AM SOMEONE WHO HAS SUCCESSFULLY CRACKED THESE INTERVIEWS, AND IF I COMPARE ATLASSIAN'S LEVEL WITH ANY FAANGM+ COMPANY INTERVIEW, I WOULD RATE IT AS 5/10. (THIS IS FOR FRESHER/INTERN INTERVIEW). SOMETIMES, I FEEL THAT WHEN PEOPLE MAKE SUCH REMARKS, THEY ARE KIND OF MAKING FUN OF THE AFFECTED INDIVIDUALS.

2. **Myth** - These people had worked hard day and night, spending 30/24 hours daily to prepare for this hellishly difficult company.
**Truth** - Most of the affected individuals are just intern converts. Now, you might say that everyone must have worked hard to prove oneself during the 8-week internship. But the fact is, most of the people had only received very basic level of work, akin to some college semester project. Some were merely asked to read a topic and create a PowerPoint presentation out of it. Additionally, most of the documentation was simply copied and pasted from previously available documents on Confluence (Atlassian's open forum where all the docs are available). Those who had the opportunity to write at least a couple of lines of code just copied it from the available codebase, sought help from seniors, and had their PRs merged by mentors themselves. Most of their time was spent in fun hours, worthless 1:1s among interns, discussing GOA trips, counting the stipend, and the CTC upon conversion.

 [**Note**: I have myself gone through some of these docs, so know the standards very well.]

I remember, that once one of the interns was asking for some valuable work, as he wanted to put atleast something on his resume, as his experience from Atlassian and all that he got was - *Bhai, itna kyun tension le rahe ho performance or experience ko leke, itna stipend kama rahe ho, jao goa-woa ghumo, masti karo jeewan jiyo, tumhare time me humlog tcs se career start karte thhe paisa hi nahi hota thha hamare paas to*
One of the other one said - *Dekho Atlassian ek already established company hai, yahaan aisa kuchh as such kaam nahi hai, agar zyada kam karne ka shauk hai to jaao kisi startup mein (then laughs).*
Once of the employee said - *Dekho Mai to khud ko yahaan prove kar chuka hoon, isliye mujhe mehnat karne ki ab utni zaroorat nahi hai, agar aaj mere paas agar koi kisi important meet ke liye aaye aur doosri taraf mera chhota bachche mujhe khelne ke liye pukaare to mai apne bachche ke paas jaaunga, kyunki I have already proven myself when I was young and a struggler, tumlog to fresher ho, kyun start kar rahe ho apni career ek work from home wali company se?*

3. The intern conversion rate for Atlassian was 95%. Moreover, in such a tough market situation, Atlassian had hired 180+ interns. Also, the 5% of interns who weren't given the PPO (actually, these were the real lucky ones) were victims of internal politics, personal grudges, or favoritism. I have seen some really good folks being treated bluntly bad, being bullied for no reason. (I had a sense of something suspicious when I saw one intern being badly scolded by a skip-level manager for no fault of his, while another intern was treated like a blessing from heaven.) By this time, I was sure that this is an actual toxic workplace, and even if I land a PPO here, it would be better to keep some backup preparation.

4. **Myth** - Remote companies offer an awesome work-life balance. Additionally, the "Work from anywhere (even hell)" concept of Atlassian is touted as really helpful.
**Truth** - However, the reality of remote work often includes a barrage of whole-day worthless meetings, a pervasive sense of laziness, with managers visibly disinterested, poor cooperation, and widespread confusion. It wasn't uncommon for people to leave their laptops open and go on long breaks, as there were numerous occasions when I messaged team members and received no reply for the entire day (sometimes even for a couple of days, as interns were seen as burdensome by the employees).
The number of interns exceeded the number of teams hosted by Atlassian India. Most managers were responsible for overseeing more than 5 interns, while mentors and buddies were tasked with mentoring multiple interns at once. With such a large intern cohort, teams struggled to allocate meaningful projects to each intern. The internship was divided into four cohorts - 20th April joiners (20 interns), 4th May joiners (30 interns), 15th May joiners (95+ interns), and 5th June joiners (~45 interns). According to teams, most project ideas had been exhausted by the first two cohorts, leaving the last cohort feeling more like a burden. (I was from the third cohort and was fortunate enough to have some meaningful tasks to work on.) Upon connecting with a peer from the last cohort, I learned that he had received his offer in August, 2022, whereas some interns from the second cohort were hired around December, 2022. The rationale behind this cohort division remains unclear.

5. The internship recruitment process at Atlassian wasn't fair. Many highly talented individuals were subjected to bullying during the interview process (the reasons behind which remain unclear). On the other hand, many average candidates were only asked questions at the level of array swapping (believe it or not, it's true). Additionally, I heard rumors about internal sourcing for certain candidates, even for on-campus placements.

6. Last year, Atlassian engaged in excessive hiring. I heard that there were expected full-time graduates who were supposed to join from July. During our team stand-ups, there was concern about what work should be assigned to these new joiners. Additionally, there were several contractors who were employed seemingly without reason and were always hovering around trying to secure some work.
Furthermore, there was a lot of advertising about an 83.54 LPA CTC at Atlassian, but the reality was just a base of 15.4 LPA.

[**About myself**] - When I landed this internship at Atlassian, a DAY 0 company, I was ecstatic. However, when I shared the news with some relatives with over 15 years of industry experience, they advised me to explore other off-campus opportunities (due to my college's single internship policy).
At that moment, I was dazzled by the 1.3L stipend. Yet, after some research and discussions with seniors, I became aware of the unpredictability surrounding Atlassian India.
During my internship, I noticed biased behavior towards certain individuals, which raised suspicions. The excessive advertising, inflated CTC, and rampant hiring in a tight market only fueled those suspicions.
After receiving the PPO, I found myself constrained again by my college's single placement policy. Just two days ago, my worst fear materialized before my eyes. I've taken these days to absorb the shock, but today, when I opened LeetCode to practice, I stumbled upon a post from someone seemingly depressed: https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-question/5042799/Atlassian-Offer-Revoked. It concerned me deeply.
I don't blame anyone for my current situation. I acknowledge that I let my serious preparation slide over the past two years because of this offer, a situation shared by almost everyone who received it. Despite numerous suggestions, I didn't pursue off-campus opportunities. In truth, I became complacent after securing the PPO.
I often pondered the misfortune of those mistreated at Atlassian or denied a PPO. Yet now, seeing them thriving in secure positions or excelling in DSA/development, I can't help but feel envious.

articles.title: Atlassian | Senior Software Engineer
articles.summary: Note:\n_1. Questions are slightly modified due to NDA.\n_2. URL-1 (mentioned later, remove spaces between characters): h t t p s : / / a t l a s s i a n b l o g
articles.content:
_Note:_
_1. Questions are slightly modified due to NDA._
_2. URL-1 (mentioned later, remove spaces between characters): h t t p s : / / a t l a s s i a n b l o g . w p e n g i n e . c o m / w p - c o n t e n t / u p l o a d s / 2 0 2 1 / 1 1 / v a l u e s - i n t e r v i e w i n g - a t l a s s i a n . p d f_

---

### DSA Round
[Find K Closest Elements](https://leetcode.com/problems/find-k-closest-elements/)

---

### Coding Round
Alongside DSA, the interviewer focused on coding and multi-threading concepts The task was to implement a **Rate Limiter**, and I started with a discussion about Fixed Window and Sliding Window.

- **Choice of Sliding Window**: The interviewer asked for a detailed explanation of both techniques and  asked to implement Sliding Window rate limiter.
- **Multi-threading**: During implementation, there was a discussion about concurrency, particularly focusing on:
  - Why I used `ConcurrentHashMap` instead of `HashMap`.
  - The use of the `synchronized` keyword.

---

### Systems Design Round

#### _For Backend Roles:_

**Context**: The interviewer used Atlassian as an example to explain a system with multiple products like Jira, Confluence, and BitBucket. Each customer may have purchased licenses for several of these products. Every product has different types of entities, such as Sprints, Features, and Tasks in Jira, documents in Confluence, and Code Repositories in BitBucket. The owner can assign hashtags to these entities.

**Example**: For a project called 'Project-XYZ', all related Jira tickets, user stories, Confluence documents, and BitBucket code reviews can be tagged with `#project-xyz` for easier tracking.

**Functional requirements**:
1. **Fetches all tagged entities**: The system should efficiently retrieve all entities owned by a customer that are tagged with a specific hashtag, across multiple products.
2. **Top 10 Hashtags**: Design a solution to identify the top 10 hashtags globally (across all customers) with the most tagged entities. Similar to "Top-K leader board problem"

**Non-functional requirements:**
1. The system should be highly configurable to allow new product types and entity types to be added.
2. Hashtags are dynamic, with no pre-defined set, meaning users can create any tag.

The focus was on schema design and choosing the right database and mapping structure for efficient querying.

#### _For Frontend Roles:_
A friend shared insights from the frontend system design round. The task was to design a dynamic sprint dashboard where users could modify the dashboard by adding columns such as “Backlog,” “Scheduled,” “In Progress,” etc. Each column could contain entities like tasks or stories.

The key areas of focus were:
- **Reusable UI Components**: The UI components, such as tasks or stories, should be reusable. For example, a Task should be rendered using the same UI component each time.
- **Versioning**: Instead of modifying existing UI components, the idea of creating a new version of the component, similar to versioning in backend systems (e.g., Maven), was emphasized.

---

### [V.Imp.] Management Round: Don't go unprepared!!
This round is for Senior Engineer roles, and **it's MANDATORY to clear, even if you ace the technical rounds!** People with 5-6 years of experience might not have had the chance to lead a project where they managed others acting as a project lead. But this round expects candidates to have managerial experience.

I strongly recommend checking `URL-1`, Atlassian’s official documentation. It lists their 5 values with 2 sample questions for each. Trust me, interviewers ask straight from this!

If you lack managerial experience, don’t admit it. Prepare responses that demonstrate your ability to lead. For example, if asked about a time when you improved someone's performance, don’t just mention helping them to learn a technology. Instead, say your colleague was newly promoted to a Senior role and was having a hard time managing resources and tracking progress. You helped him with best practices that you learned from your experience, such as setting up a dedicated project call outside of the daily standup to thoroughly assess progress. This response shows you understand team dynamics and can coach others.

Every answer should aim to showcase strong managerial experience and knowledge of best practices. The interviewer will be a manager!

___

### Values round
Everything I said about the managerial round applies exactly to this one as well.

---

### Preparation
For details on how I prepared, check out my [Google interview experience blog](https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-question/5547675/Google-Interview-questions-and-preparation/).

articles.title: Keep grinding it works !!
articles.summary: Hi all,TLDR - Grind for about 8 months and nothing in hand, now have offers from Amazon, Uber, Atlassian, Microsoft. Want to give back to community.This is in continuation to my last post I posted few months earlierhttps://leetcode.com/discuss/post/5
articles.content:
Hi all,


TLDR - Grind for about 8 months and nothing in hand, now have offers from Amazon, Uber, Atlassian, Microsoft. Want to give back to community.


This is in continuation to my last post I posted few months earlier 

https://leetcode.com/discuss/post/5688796/what-am-i-doing-wrong-with-interview-pre-4ne9/

TC - 75LPA
YOE - 5Y

# Journey

I was facing lot of issues in getting interview and was very frustated, to summarize I had started preparation in May'24 and by end of the year I had given interviews of almost all major companies and lots of startups and mid sized comapnies with just one very low balled offer. Few ghosted after clearing all the rounds and many gave random reasons for rejection. 
I was devasted after getting all these rejections but fortunately decided not to give up, kept working for it.

# Results

Coming to Mar'25 I got my first offer which I thought is a good one. It's a mid-sized company and they were good work in e-commerce domain, I was particularly very excited but decided its time to move on and took the offer. I had few interviews lined up and this is when things started to really work in my favour. Few days after this I got an acceptance from Microsoft. I was very very happy, they offered lot better compensation and we all know about the perks. I kept giving interviews in my lineup, later on converted Uber and Atlassian as well. I was waiting on writing this post as I was yet to hear from Amazon and got an acceptance from Amazon as well. I have decided to go ahead with Atlassian but I am now very confident that I would be able to get the most out of myself and work to my full potential with confidence.

# Why am I writing this ? 

This is not a brag post, I generally don't like to talk about this. I am writing this to tell anyone who is going through the same phase as I was few months back that if you keep working towards it you will definitely see results. I myself had kinda given up and thought that there is no pickng up my career from here but kept faith in myself and made it work. This post is to tell you to keep faith in yourself and keep all the negative thoughts out of your mind and just keep working towards it. Also I have learnt a lot from going through different leetcode posts and this is my way of giving back to the community, I would also be answering each and every question in detail and to best of my abilities. 

# What I would do differently going ahead ? 

1. Being organized really really help, keep a tab on the list of comapnies you can apply and keep following up.
2. LinkedIn network work, I am in the process of optimizing my linkedin network so I can see more relevant posts which would give me good market overview. 
3. Organized studies - I was always hoping that next comapny should be the one and therefore was always just studying keeping the next interview I have in mind because of which I had to go through many things repeatdely. Instead focusing on the next interview I would focus on all the topics I have to cover and study them in depth.

# Conclusion

Many thanks to everyone who has been directly or indirectly part of my journey and helped me, thanks to the community.

articles.title: Atlassian | SDE-3 | Remote | India | Offer
articles.summary: HR screening round: The HR asked me some basic questions like trees, binary search, some database questions, and about my work and experience.\n\nKarat- The for
articles.content:
HR screening round: The HR asked me some basic questions like trees, binary search, some database questions, and about my work and experience.

Karat- The format was to spend 20 minutes on 5 system design questions and 30 minutes on coding, where two questions had to be solved with running code. LeetCode medium and another hard-level question.
I could choose to redo this round within 48 hours, and the best of the two rounds would be considered for evaluation. I wasn't feeling positive and decided to redo.
Personally I felt this is a difficult one due to its strict time bound policy.
I cleared this round, and HR scheduled the next round. Every round was an elimination round.

Code design - I was given a real-world design statement and had to code it with an executable solution. Function signatures were given. It involved some system-level APIs as well. The interviewer asked about its internals and discussed if I had to implement what change I would implement to make it more usable, efficient etc. The code was tested against some test cases.

Data structures - It involved solving a problem with a combination of data structures, and you had to write code in a way that you could extend it to implement the follow-up question. I made a small mistake, used the wrong map, and some test cases were failing. But after some debugging, I figured it out.

System design - I was asked to design a question similar to social media. We had a discussion on various DB tables, which database to use and why, what are some features of that database, API endpoints, minimum possible API endpoints and DB tables, pagination, indexing, user experience. The follow-up was about changes I would make to the system and why if I got a second chance.

Values - I was asked a "tell me about a time" type of question, but the focus was on Atlassian values.

Managerial - I was asked several questions about my past experiences dealing with situations of conflict, teamwork, team leading, cross-organization impact, etc.

My advice - Don’t take the managerial and values rounds lightly. Based on the performance in these rounds, Atlassian can downlevel or even reject you. For senior roles P50, P60, these two rounds are most important, and the questions they ask are not that easy to answer compared to SDE2 or lower levels. Expectations are high for these roles.

Atlassian's compensation is on par with Microsoft, Amazon, and Google.

And finally, I cleared the interviews and happily joined the organization.

feel free to connect me at https://www.linkedin.com/in/puneet-saini-61a2b48a/

articles.title: Interview experience
articles.summary: I recently interviewed for the P40 role at Atlassian, and I wanted to share my experience. The feedback from all my rounds was positive, except for the manageri
articles.content:
I recently interviewed for the P40 role at Atlassian, and I wanted to share my experience. The feedback from all my rounds was positive, except for the managerial round, where I received a "Weak Hire/No Hire" evaluation.

I was really surprised by this outcome because I felt that the managerial round went pretty well. I was confident in my responses and in demonstrating my leadership and communication skills. Given that the rest of my feedback was positive, I'm left wondering about the impact of the managerial round and how much weight it carries in the final decision.

Has anyone else experienced a similar situation? What do you think the chances are when you get positive feedback in technical rounds but mixed feedback in the managerial round?

Would appreciate any insights or thoughts!

articles.title: Atlassian | Senior Software Engineer | Bengaluru | August [Offer]
articles.summary:
Status: 10 YOE
Company: Walmart Global Tech
Location: Bengaluru
Date: August, 2024

1st round (Screening - Karat)
System Design questions:
1. Any concern
articles.content:
Status: 10 YOE
Company: Walmart Global Tech
Location: Bengaluru
Date: August, 2024

**1st round (Screening - Karat)**
System Design questions:
1. Any concerns with Consistent Hashing for multiple servers serving music uploading/streaming service
2. How would you handle large files that cannot fit in on a single machine
3. How would you scale your backend if your app is going from a single country to international app
4. Pros and cons of preloading hints or loading them from server for a game. Hints could be text/image/video based.

DSA:
1. Given a main word and a list of words, we need to find the word from the list whose anagram is present in a given string. HashMap problem
2. Find the coordinate of the given word in a n*m grid. Can start from any where and only move right/down

**2nd round (DSA)**
Given a stream of events with contentId and its popularity trend (+1/-1) we need to provide the most popular contentId at any given point in O(1)
https://leetcode.com/problems/all-oone-data-structure/

**3rd round (Machine Coding)**
Rate limiter (Token bucket) Was asked to implement any one strategy

**4th round (High Level design)**
Tag management system: We need to design a tagging system that different systems like Confluence and Jira should be able to use to tag their assets.

**5th round (Management)**
1. Did you ever put your team ahead of your personal goals?
2. Did you take any initiative to improve the current system in your team?
3. Did you ever oppose someone’s technical approach and how?
4. What was the most challenging task you have faced?
5. Did you ever convince other teams to align with your thought process?

**6th round (Values)**
1. Biggest challenge you faced so far in your career?
2. Did you ever put your team ahead of your personal goals?
3. Did you face any issues with any teammates performance how did you?resolve it?
4. Did you ever commit anything and were not able to deliver it on time?
5. Did you drive any change in the team which ultimately for rejected?

Do not take 5th and 6th rounds lightly, they are as important as the technical rounds especially if it is P50 and above. Go prepared with good amount of examples.

Questions around Atlassian values.

articles.title: Atlassian
articles.content:
R2 (code design round) :
Design a middleware router
/**
interface Router {

  fun addRoute(path: String, result: String) : Unit;
  
  fun callRoute(path: String) : String;
  
}

Usage:
Router.addRoute("/bar", "result")
Router.callRoute("/bar") -> output : "result"
Router.addRoute("/foo/bar", "result2")
Router.callRoute("/foo/bar") -> output: "result2"
**/

R3 (Data structure) :
/*
Imagine we have a system that stores files, and these files can be grouped into collections. We are interested in knowing where our resources are being taken up.

For this system we would like to generate a report that lists:

The total size of all files stored; and

The top N collections (by file size) where N can be a user-defined value

An example input into your report generator might look like:

file1.txt (size: 100)
file2.txt (size: 200) in collection "collection1"
file3.txt (size: 200) in collection "collection1"
file4.txt (size: 300) in collection "collection2"
file5.txt (size: 10)

output : 
total size = 100+400+300+10 = 810
top 2 collection = collection1 
collection2
*/
Got rejected even after correct solution in both round.  #shitlassian

articles.title: Atlassian | P50 | Bangalore | April 2024 [Reject]
articles.summary:
Status: 7+ years of experience in backend development
Position: SSE at Walmart
Location: Bangalore, India
Date: April 2024
Total Process Time: Approximately
articles.content:
Status: 7+ years of experience in backend development
Position: SSE at Walmart
Location: Bangalore, India
Date: April 2024
Total Process Time: Approximately 1 to 1.5 months

Karat Round (1 hour):

One coding question with a lengthy input and expected output, such as an array of strings of strings. The logic was simple, but I don’t remember the exact question. It was of medium or easy to medium difficulty.
Five theoretical system design questions. Try to provide as many points as possible. For example, to improve system latency, you can mention adding cache, CDN for static content, adding database indexes, etc. Each question has 5 minutes allotted, and HR will share a format for the same.
Result: Selected
1st Technical with Atlassian LLD or Design (1 hour):

Atlassian often asks about designing a rate limiter, which was the case for me as well (x requests in y time). I proposed a moving window approach, but I was removing all requests from the queue within the time window. The interviewer suggested processing only one request, reducing the time complexity from O(windowLength) to O(1). The interview went well, and the interviewer was very friendly. We finished a bit early and talked about common hobbies, etc.
2nd Technical with Atlassian or DS:

In this round, they asked about a voting algorithm where each person gets votes in order (e.g., (ABC) -> A having 3 votes, B 2, and C 1). The goal was to return the most voted person. This question is common in many Atlassian rounds. Then, they asked a similar version, focusing on how I would handle the algorithm, follow the Open-Closed Principle, and add a function to the interface. The coding rounds were not hard; just follow standard design processes.
3rd HLD:

Designed a service to get the most viewed or liked page. Discussion points included:
How to maintain a list of likes. Should I maintain viewed IDs or just a count? Pros and cons.
Handling a scenario where a new page becomes the most liked next year while still showing users the previous year's top page. I proposed using a NoSQL database mapped to each day with a list of pages, but the interviewer preferred Cassandra DB, stating we wouldn’t consider this year's data. I was unsure how to solve this, resulting in a pass with a P40 ranking, which decreased my interest in Atlassian.
4th Managerial:

I expected a mix of technical and behavioral questions, but it was entirely behavioral. The interviewer expected STAR format answers, and I felt I didn't perform well. Overall, it was a simple round.
5th Values:

Focused on Atlassian's five values. Prepare a story for each value and answer in the STAR format. Nothing special.
Overall, I did well in the Karat round and the first two technical rounds but was weak in the HLD and managerial rounds. The main rejection came from the managerial round, but I was approved in the values round. In my experience, cracking Atlassian isn't that hard; you don't need to solve all of LeetCode and lots of DS questions. Prepare some design patterns, stay confident, stay calm during interviews, and have a sip of water if needed. However, I don't like their practice of downgrading to lower roles, which they do often. I also heard they revoked offers for freshers, so I was a bit skeptical during the interview.

Request for Community:
I am good at DS and have passed DS rounds in all my interviews but have failed in HLD and sometimes in LLD. Any tips for improvement?

articles.title: Interview Exp:  Atlassian Full Stack Developer | Worst Experience
articles.summary: So, I was exicited to give this interview for Atlassain as I heard a lot about how good the org is, and belive me when i say this that this was the worst interv
articles.content:
So, I was exicited to give this interview for Atlassain as I heard a lot about how good the org is, and belive me when i say this that this was the worst interview exp I ever had. Here is the timeline for complete set of events.

Jan 8th - Mail from HR: Are you available to give the test and first round by 13th jan. And also let me know if you are up for the quick intro call. 
Jan 8th - Me: Yes

Jan 13th - No communication from HR side
Jan 13th - I replied on the mail saying, are you going to schedule the Online test or not. But again got no reply of any kind.

Jan 21st - I got a mail notification that HR schedule the first round of interview at 10pm next Day. Funny part is she mailed me about this at 11 in the night and not even without asking me for my availbility or anything.

I ignored this and continues on to give the test on next day

Jan 24th - I replied on the same mail, asking for feedback or update. but got no response
Jan 27th - Again i ask for feedback or update. but got no response

I thaught i am rejected and hence stopped asking.

1month down the line

Feb 22nd - I got a mail from HR that they are moving ahead with my profile and she said she will be scheduling my next round on 27 and 28 so be free between 1 pm to 5pm, she can schedule any where between this time slot. ( who does that)
And again she told me she will be giving me intro/prep call for next round and she scheduled the zoom call for the same for the next day

I acknowledged the mail..

Feb 23rd - I joined the zoom call, making some time from office schedule and this time again she didnt joined and also not bothered to  give update of any kind.

I replied on the same mail ki whats this behaviour, she said sorry I will be calling you tommorow but again same story....

days went by  but i got no update from her and she just simply ghosted me after saying they are moving ahead with my candidature. 

Man, I am telling you, I expected better interview exp with Atlassian...

articles.title: Atlassian P50 Karat stage
articles.summary: for the DSA partDSA Question 1A list of strings representing the available parts in the factory bin.A string representing the comma-separated list of required parts needed to fully build one robot.Function Signature: public static String[] get_robots
articles.content:
for the DSA part

# **DSA Question 1**


A list of strings representing the available parts in the factory bin.

A string representing the comma-separated list of required parts needed to fully build one robot.

```
Task: Implement a function that returns the list of robot names for which we can build at least one complete robot from the available parts.
```
Function Signature: **public static String[] get_robots(String[] all_parts, String required_parts)**

Sample Input:
String[] all_parts = { "Rosie_claw",
 "Rosie_sensors",
 "Dustie_case",
 "Optimus_sensors",
 "Rust_sensors",
 "Rosie_case",
 "Rust_case",
 "Optimus_speaker",
 "Rosie_wheels",
 "Rosie_speaker",
 "Dustie_case",
 "Dustie_arms",
 "Rust_claw",
 "Dustie_case",
 "Dustie_speaker",
 "Optimus_case",
 "Optimus_wheels",
 "Rust_legs",
 "Optimus_sensors" };


String required_parts_1 = "sensors,case,speaker,wheels"; 
String required_parts_2 = "sensors,case,speaker,wheels,claw"; 
String required_parts_3 = "sensors,case,screws";

**Expected Output:**
get_robots(all_parts, required_parts_1) => ["Optimus", "Rosie"]
get_robots(all_parts, required_parts_2) => ["Rosie"] 
get_robots(all_parts, required_parts_3) => []

***My Solution that is accepted by the interviewer and passed all tests***. 
1. create a map of robot to set of spare parts. 
2. Check if all the required materials are in the set.. those robots that have all parts are the response.


# **DSA Question 2**
You work in an automated robot factory. Once robots are assembled, they are sent to the shipping center via a series of autonomous delivery carts, each of which moves packages on a one-way route.

```
Given input that provides the (directed) steps that each cart takes as pairs, write a function that identifies all the start locations, and a collection of all of the possible ending locations for each start location.
```

In this diagram, starting locations are at the top and destinations are at the bottom - i.e. the graph is directed exclusively downward.

   A          E      J       Key:  [Origins]
  / \        / \      \                 \
 B   C      F   L      M             [Destinations]
  \ /  \   /
   K     G
        / \
       H   I

paths = [ 
  ["B", "K"],
  ["C", "K"],
  ["E", "L"],
  ["F", "G"],
  ["J", "M"],
  ["E", "F"],
  ["C", "G"],
  ["A", "B"],
  ["A", "C"],
  ["G", "H"],
  ["G", "I"]
]

**Expected output (unordered):**  
[ 
  "A": ["K", "H", "I"], 
  "E": ["H", "L", "I"],
  "J": ["M"]
]

N: Number of pairs in the input.

.........

***didn't finish this one..***

**solution whose idea was accepted by the interviewer and that i have started coding**

 1. create a a graph and find the nodes that don't have inbound edge
 2. from those nodes run dfs to find all the nodes that are leaves (no children)

articles.title: Loom technical assessment [Rejected][Senior SWE]
articles.summary: Ended up failing this technical screen only passing 3/4 test cases by the end of the interview. Anyone have ideas on how this could be solved optimally? Questio
articles.content:
Ended up failing this technical screen only passing 3/4 test cases by the end of the interview. Anyone have ideas on how this could be solved optimally? Question is summarized into basically:

***You are given a series of intervals for what a user wants to "trim" from a video of a given duration. Find all non-trimmed segments of the video***

I was given the following snippet and expected to implement *calculate_inverse_range*

```
def test_example_1():   
    duration_1 = 40
    sample_input_1 = [
        { "from": 5, "to": 15 },
        { "from": 25, "to": 30 },
    ]

    assert calculate_inverse_range(sample_input_1, duration_1) == \
        [
            { "from": 0, "to": 5 },
            { "from": 15, "to": 25 },
            { "from": 30, "to": 40 }
        ]

def test_example_2():
    duration_2 = 40
    sample_input_2 = [
        { "from": 0, "to": 2 },
        { "from": 5, "to": 15 },
        { "from": 25, "to": 30 },
    ]

    assert calculate_inverse_range(sample_input_2, duration_2) == \
        [
            { "from": 2, "to": 5 },
            { "from": 15, "to": 25 },
            { "from": 30, "to": 40 }
        ]
 
def test_example_3():
    duration_3 = 40
    sample_input_3 = [
        { "from": 0, "to": 10 },
        { "from": 1, "to": 6 },
        { "from": 4, "to": 5 },
        { "from": 2, "to": 8 },
        { "from": 15, "to": 20 },
        { "from": 25, "to": 30 },
    ]
    assert calculate_inverse_range(sample_input_3, duration_3) == \
        [
            { "from": 10, "to": 15 },
            { "from": 20, "to": 25 },
            { "from": 30, "to": 40 }
        ]

def test_example_4():
    duration_4 = 60
    sample_input_4 = [
        { "from": 10, "to": 20 },
        { "from": 5, "to": 15 },
        { "from": 35, "to": 50 },
        { "from": 30, "to": 40 },
    ]
    assert calculate_inverse_range(sample_input_4, duration_4) == \
        [
            { "from": 0, "to": 5 },
            { "from": 20, "to": 30 },
            { "from": 50, "to": 60 }
        ]

pytest.main()
```

My solution for the first 3 test cases came down to an *n * log(n)* algorithm that relied on first sorting the from earliest trims to latest, then walking through and constructing the inverse. It's pretty messy but I had trouble conceptulaizing the task and eventually came up with:

```
def calculate_inverse_range(trim_ranges, duration):
    sorted_trim_ranges = sorted(trim_ranges, key=lambda t: t["from"])

    i = 0
    previous_interval = None
    current_interval = None
    intervals = []
    
    while True:
        if i > (len(sorted_trim_ranges) - 1):
            break

        current_interval = sorted_trim_ranges[i]

        if current_interval["from"] != 0:
            begin = previous_interval["to"] if previous_interval else 0
            end = current_interval["from"]

            intervals.append({
                "from": begin,
                "to": end
            })

        previous_interval = current_interval
        i += 1
    
    if current_interval["to"] != duration:
        intervals.append({
            "from": current_interval["to"],
            "to": duration
        })
    
    return intervals
```

The fourth test case involved collapsing overlapping intervals, which I struggled to come up with a quick solution for and ended up with a brute-force N^2 algorithm that *almost* worked by modifying the ranges but I didn't manage to get it working (I needed to also remove the now-merged ranges)

```
def collapse_ranges(sorted_trim_ranges):
    """
        { "from": 5, "to": 15 },
        { "from": 10, "to": 20 },
        { "from": 35, "to": 50 },
        { "from": 30, "to": 40 },
    """
    
    range_map = []

    for i in range(len(sorted_trim_ranges)):
        inclusive_overlapping = False

        start = sorted_trim_ranges[i]["from"]
        end = sorted_trim_ranges[i]["to"]

        for j in range(i):
            if (
                sorted_trim_ranges[i]["from"] > sorted_trim_ranges[j]["from"] and
                sorted_trim_ranges[i]["to"] < sorted_trim_ranges[j]["to"]
            ):
                inclusive_overlapping = True
            elif (
                ( sorted_trim_ranges[i]["from"] > sorted_trim_ranges[j]["from"] and
                    sorted_trim_ranges[i]["from"] < sorted_trim_ranges[j]["to"]
                ) and
                sorted_trim_ranges[i]["to"] > sorted_trim_ranges[j]["to"]
            ):
                # New range begins at previous start, current end
                start = sorted_trim_ranges[j]["from"]
                end = sorted_trim_ranges[i]["to"]
        
        if not inclusive_overlapping:
            range_map.append({
                "from": start,
                "to": end
            })
        

    return range_map
```
	
Any thoughts / ideas on how I could have solved this optimally?

articles.summary:
/

We are working on a security system for a badged-access room in our company's building.

Given an ordered list of employees who used their badge to ente
articles.content:
/*

We are working on a security system for a badged-access room in our company's building.

Given an ordered list of employees who used their badge to enter or exit the room, write a function that returns two collections:

1. All employees who didn't use their badge while exiting the room - they recorded an enter without a matching exit. (All employees are required to leave the room before the log ends.)

2. All employees who didn't use their badge while entering the room - they recorded an exit without a matching enter. (The room is empty when the log begins.)

Each collection should contain no duplicates, regardless of how many times a given employee matches the criteria for belonging to it.

records1 = [
  ["Paul",     "enter"],
  ["Pauline",  "exit"],
  ["Paul",     "enter"],
  ["Paul",     "exit"],
  ["Martha",   "exit"],
  ["Joe",      "enter"],
  ["Martha",   "enter"],
  ["Steve",    "enter"],
  ["Martha",   "exit"],
  ["Jennifer", "enter"],
  ["Joe",      "enter"],
  ["Curtis",   "exit"],
  ["Curtis",   "enter"],
  ["Joe",      "exit"],
  ["Martha",   "enter"],
  ["Martha",   "exit"],
  ["Jennifer", "exit"],
  ["Joe",      "enter"],
  ["Joe",      "enter"],
  ["Martha",   "exit"],
  ["Joe",      "exit"],
  ["Joe",      "exit"] 
]
                    ENTER W/O EXIT                      EXIT W/O ENTER
Expected output: ["Steve", "Curtis", "Paul", "Joe"], ["Martha", "Pauline", "Curtis", "Joe"]

Other test cases:

records2 = [
  ["Paul", "enter"],
  ["Paul", "exit"],
]

Expected output: [], []

records3 = [
  ["Paul", "enter"],
  ["Paul", "enter"],
  ["Paul", "exit"],
  ["Paul", "exit"],
]

Expected output: ["Paul"], ["Paul"]

records4 = [
  ["Raj", "enter"],
  ["Paul", "enter"],
  ["Paul", "exit"],
  ["Paul", "exit"],
  ["Paul", "enter"],
  ["Raj", "enter"],
]

Expected output: ["Raj", "Paul"], ["Paul"]

All Test Cases:
mismatches(records1) => ["Steve", "Curtis", "Paul", "Joe"], ["Martha", "Pauline", "Curtis", "Joe"]
mismatches(records2) => [], []
mismatches(records3) => ["Paul"], ["Paul"]
mismatches(records4) => ["Raj", "Paul"], ["Paul"]

n: length of the badge records array

*/

public class Solution {
  public static final String ENTER = "enter";
  public static final String EXIT = "exit";
  public static void main(String[] argv) {
    String[][] records1 = {
      {"Paul", "enter"}, //no issue
      {"Pauline", "exit"}, // issue, means she entered the room w/o using badge, exit w/o enter
      {"Paul", "enter"},
      {"Paul", "exit"},
      {"Martha", "exit"},
      {"Joe", "enter"},
      {"Martha", "enter"},
      {"Steve", "enter"},
      {"Martha", "exit"},
      {"Jennifer", "enter"},
      {"Joe", "enter"},
      {"Curtis", "exit"},
      {"Curtis", "enter"},
      {"Joe", "exit"},
      {"Martha", "enter"},
      {"Martha", "exit"},
      {"Jennifer", "exit"},
      {"Joe", "enter"},
      {"Joe", "enter"},
      {"Martha", "exit"},
      {"Joe", "exit"},
      {"Joe", "exit"},
    };

    String[][] records2 = {
      {"Paul", "enter"},
      {"Paul", "exit"},
    };

    String[][] records3 = {
      {"Paul", "enter"},
      {"Paul", "enter"},
      {"Paul", "exit"},
      {"Paul", "exit"},
    };

    String[][] records4 = {
      {"Raj", "enter"},
      {"Paul", "enter"},
      {"Paul", "exit"},
      {"Paul", "exit"},
      {"Paul", "enter"},
      {"Raj", "enter"},
    };
    
    
     Map<String, Set<String>> res = checkEmployeeRecord(records4); 
     System.out.println(res.get("enter"));
     System.out.println(res.get("exit"));
  }

articles.summary: I interviwed for senior software engg position and got a verbal offer.\n\nRound 1: Input list of , output a dashboard containining total size of the files and t
articles.content:
I interviwed for senior software engg position and got a verbal offer.

Round 1: Input list of <file_name, int size of file>, output a dashboard containining total size of the files and top N files (file largest in size)
Round 2: https://leetcode.com/problems/all-oone-data-structure/
The third round involved designing a tag service system. 
The fourth round focused on managerial aspects, while the fifth round assessed values.
Overall the interviwered were cooperative and awesome.

The recruiter on the other hand were untrustable.
They promissed a raise over current TC initially  (after telling them upfront TC composition before interview and also after 2 interviews)

When I cleared all the interviews the recruiter denied they ever had TC related conversation before and tried to convince me to take a cut in TC and join them.

On glassdoor also I found the same issue recurring with other candidate so just beware folks, keep your hopes low when dealing with Atlassian.

articles.title: Atlassian - File System Design
articles.summary: Design a file system to support getting the size of any directory.\n\nWhat could be a better approach for this problem if size of any directory needs to be retu
articles.content:
***Design a file system to support getting the size of any directory.***

What could be a better approach for this problem if size of any directory needs to be returned in O(1) ignoring the cost to traverse from root to given directory. Multiple files can be added to the directory and it's sub directories.
How to keep the directory size updated whenever a new content is added to directory.

2. Full Stack Craft Interview: this round majorly focused on end to web application flow.
     - Talking about how endpoint execution happens through browser. (DNS resolution, router and ISPs.)
     - Different protocols discussion between client and server communication.
     - How certificates are used with https?

Had a call with recruiter and result came out to be positive. Now moving further with 3 more rounds.

2. Leadership deep dive on projects (behavioral)
3. Values (behavioral)

articles.title: Atlassian | SDE Intern 2023 | India | Nov 2022 [Selected]
articles.summary:
About the Internship:

Atlassian hired for SDE Interns for 2 months summer internship off-campus in September 2022.

Internship Duration : May to July 2023\
articles.content:
About the Internship:

Atlassian hired for SDE Interns for 2 months summer internship off-campus in September 2022.

Internship Duration : May to July 2023

Application Process:

1. Application Form:

	The application form asked for some personal details.
	Almost all the eligible candidates got the test link.
	
2. Online Coding Round: (in October 2022)

	Conducted on HackerRank Platform.
	Duration : 90 minutes
	4 coding questions
	Level of Test : Medium to Hard
	
	My Experience:

	1 easy question on Arrays.
	2 medium questions on Strings and Dynamic Programming.
	1 hard question on 3D Dynamic Programming.
	
	I solved 3 questions fully and 1 partially (11/15 tc passed).
	Got the shortlist mail for interviews.
	
3. Technical Interview: (in November 2023)

	Duration: 40–45 mins
	DSA Question or Real Life Based Problem to solve using Data Structures and Algorithms
	Level of Interview : Medium to Hard
	
	My experience:

	Was asked a Real Life Based Problem to solve using most appropriate Data Structure and Algorithm.
	Thing covered in Interview : Brute Force and it’s Time Complexity, Optimized Approach and its time complexity , Code and then dry run over some test cases.
	Some theory based questions and internal working of STL containers.
	
	Solved the question and answered all the theory based questions.
	Got shortlisted for second interview.
	
4. Managerial and Values Interview: (same day as Technical Interview)

	Duration: 40–45 mins
	HR based questions
	No technical questions
	
	My experience:

	I was asked about college life, past achievements.
	Some Situational Based Questions with past experiences like:
	Do you believe in sharing your knowledge and any past experience on this?
	Any day someone took decision for you but you were against it, what did you do? with some past experience
	and many more questions like this.
	
	Result: In January 2023, Got the selection mail for the Summer Internship.
